intro: Salvia amana, commonly known as the Mexican sage, is a perennial herb native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a rough texture. Its flowers are usually purple or violet, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Salvia amana is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine.
